answers.answer: Hi.  I'm not a medical professional, just the parent of a kid with diabetes.  I'd say if he still wants you to go, that's ok, as long as he takes responsibility for what's going on and asks all the questions.  That sounds like what is going on, so it could just be that he's recognizing the efforts that you've made in taking care of him up until now by wanting to include you.  It's a comfort level thing for him.  I think you should talk to him about eventually not going, but if it's still important to him, it's not a bad thing.

question: My son is 24 and has been diabetic since he was 12.  I still go with him to his doctor visits partly because over the years he has had some doctors that we have had to wait 2-3 hours to see.  He also doesn't really like to go to the doctors because he knows they are always going to say this is wrong or that is wrong.  His a1c runs 7.2, he does struggle with high blood pressure, and yes there is always some improvement that might help, but now most of the advice sounds more like criticism.--he checks his blood about 10 times a day. So I think he likes me there for moral support--I really don't say much other than hi; he is the one who discusses whatever with the doctor.  I guess my real question is, is it ok that he still wants me at the appointments, and that most of the time I try to be available to go?
title: doctor visits
